dialogues.text: (serious; to the Firebird) I love you. Is that weird? He opens the bar fridge and swipes out a beer, gropes for bottle opener. Can’t find it. He gives up, smacks the cap the edge of the bench. The whole neck of the bottle shatt

dialogues.speaker: HANDLEY
dialogues.text: You could never turn me off. Don’t forget the presentation tomorrow morning for the board.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Damn it, I left my notes at the office.

dialogues.speaker: HANDLEY

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t worry about Handley. He crunches numbers for a living so that’s his approach to women. If he hits on everyone, mathematical law dictates that someone will say yes eventually. She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Working hard I see, judging by the beer on your breath.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Actually...I was working hard. I just finished the Firebird.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I gotta drop it off to the guy tonight. He’s obsessed with me being on time. He’s kinda nuts.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Have fun.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: You're coming with me.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: What? Why?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: How else am I gonna get home? Asha sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Okay. Grey grins and pulls her in tight.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA, (CONT'D)

dialogues.text: What are we waiting for?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: It's gotta be eight exactly before I can...forget it, just go with me. (beat) By the way, he kind of butts in when you talk to him. Don’t let it get to you. dialogues.text: Yes I was standing here waiting is this your wife?

dialogues.text: Ah, yes. I’m his wife. Asha. Hi.  He doesn’t offer his hand. Speaks very quickly.

dialogues.text: Come inside to eat dinner.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Ah...we’d love to stay, but we --

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: The dinner’s already been prepared, it’s ready now if you don’t eat it then it’s wasted. Grey turns to Asha, then back to Eron.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Okay then. Bottoms up. INT. CORRIDOR, ERON KEEN’S MANSION - NIGHT Eron leads the befuddled pair down a long corridor. He is walking much quicker than they are.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Nice suit. I didn’t think of you --

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I don’t have people over very often so I thought I’d dress for it.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: It’s a beautiful house.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Thank you I find it a little antiseptic I swear I’m not a germaphobe. I can’t stand that. A cliche of the wealthy. Why do only rich people suffer that? dialogues.text: Grey tells me you work at the company Cobolt.

dialogues.text: Uh...yes. Yes, I do. I’ve been --

dialogues.text: Your company specializes in prosthetic limbs. That’s a very interesting subject to me.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: No, that’s wrong. Two. I said two. Grey is perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What’s that? Eron points to his ear. He’s having a phone conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I know what I said, I said it.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: (to Grey) He’s on the phone. Eron plucks a tiny black earpiece out of his ear, frustra dropping it into a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh...so you collect old cars?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I’m fascinated by the exterior aesthetic of the period which we’ve still not managed to match since then, even with all our technological advances. My life’s work is about taking something timeless and built with care, like that car or this house, and then retrofitting it with the most up to date system. State of the art technology with a classic skin.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Wait...so you’re gonna rip the engine out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually. Not right away. I want to study how it works.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Seems a shame to get rid of... Asha glares at Grey to drop it. Eron finishes eating.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I’1l1 show you what would replace it. Let’s go to my factory.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: We really can’t go anywhere else --

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: It’s on the property right behind the house. I don’t like to leave the grounds. We'll be very quick. EXT. dialogues.text: This is the worldwide headquarters and research lab of my company, Vessel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This chip represents my present and the rest of the world’s future.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: What does it do?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Literally anything. We see the computer chips POV - encompassing the whole ro

dialogues.text: Really? So this thing can make babies and play football? Wow.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: It can drive anything, talk to any piece of equipment, calculate anything. It’s a new, better brain.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: (with a smile) You look at that widget and see the future. I see ten guys on an unemployment line.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: (getting testy) It’s about efficiency. I’m sure when the car was invented there were people in the horse and cart business who felt they were being urinated on.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’ve tasted the piss shower myself. My job used to be drivin’ a freight crane, until one day they decided a computer could do it better. Twenty of us replaced overnight, by something like that thing.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: Grey...

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: It’s hard for a human to compete with a computer. They don’t take sick days. They don’t need weekends off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They also can’t have a beer with you at the end of the week. The conversation has gone sour. Eron closes the safe.

dialogues.speaker: ERON

dialogues.text: He brought it up.

dialogues.text: You didn’t have to take the bait. Grey stares at the steering wheel for the car, turning languidly on its own.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I was always a good driver. Always loved cars. He reaches up and absently runs his fingers over the stee wheel. The car’s computer chirps in a neutral pleasant vo

dialogues.text: Please do not touch the steering wheel while the car is in motion. Grey sits back.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do when his microchip is running the world?

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Arriving at Cobolt. The car purrs to a halt outside a city skyscraper.

dialogues.speaker: ASHA
dialogues.text: I'll be back in two seconds, I’ve just gotta grab my notes. She exits, leaving Grey to stew alone.  10.

dialogues.text: So who are they?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: It...would also appear that they had some sort of firewall built around their chip. A blocking screen that makes it next to impossible to glean any data.  20. Grey looks away, shaking his head. Boiling.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s very common for criminals to have firewalls like this installed. Hackers will do it, a back room job. A thousand dollars effectively gets you taken off the grid.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So you got nothin’?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Not right now. Nothing concrete.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So what you’re telling me is that you've built this police state that tracks all of us - except the bastards you need to go after.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: That’s not the way we're going to catch these guys. I’m a detective and I still believe in old fashioned detective work...even if I’m the last person who does. That means patient elimination of leads and small victories. I’m not sitting at a computer, I’m down in that neighborhood, knocking on doors. I’ve conducted interviews with several people of interest, but so far --

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: They didn’t live in that neighborhood, I know that. This wasn’t some random robbery, they fucked with our car. They took over the computer in it. You think some gangbanger shithead can do that?! Pamela enters, alarmed by the shouting. She stays at the of the room.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: I know it’s frustrating. You have to let me do it my way and concentrate on your own recovery. I need you to save your strength for that fight.  21.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: There is no fight. I’m never going to recover - it’s a permanent spinal injury.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Don’t say that. You gotta keep your spirit up. Doctor’s are capable of amazing things.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Just because I can’t tie my own shoes anymore doesn’t mean you have to lie to me like I’m a god damn three year old.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Grey. I wish I had better news for you regarding the case. Cortez gathers her things and leaves. Pam closes the door

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA
dialogues.text: She’s on your side.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Can you leave too, please?

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA
dialogues.text: I need to be here. To take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No. You don’t. I have machines to do that. There’s nothing you can do that they can’t. Please leave. He turns his chair away from her. Pamela stays where she minute, then approaches him. She wraps her arms around hi At first he resists...then rests his head on her shoulder INT. BEDROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Grey lies in bed, his own body weighing him down. He glar at the photo of Asha, tears in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Morphine. The robot arm connected to his bed extends, injecting Gre GREY (CONT’D) Morphine.  22. The robot arm injects him again. GREY (CONT’D) Morphine. The robot arm complies. GREY (CONT’D) Again.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I cannot supply any more morphine. The arm moves to Grey’s face. When it is close enough, Gr rips the needle from the robots grip with his teeth, jamm it into his sternum. He eases back, overcome by the drug. INT. BEDROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - NIGHT - LATER The machine besides his bed suddenly PINGS loudly, soundi an ALARM. Red light washes over Grey as lights on the mac sparks to life. The scream of a siren takes us into -- EXT. ST. VINCENT’S HOSPITAL - DAY - ESTABLISHING -- a large building downtown. A hybrid of old and new. INT. GREY’S ROOM, ST. VINCENT’S HOSPITAL - DAY Grey is splayed across a gurney, staring through the wind His mother sits at the end of the bed, eyes red with tear

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA
dialogues.text: All of us are going to die one day, Grey. Please give me a chance to help you find hope before I do. A tall figure appears at the doorway to Grey’s room, dres in a black suit, carrying a very thin briefcase. This is NIKOLAI (43), a humorless Russian man.

dialogues.speaker: NIKOLAI
dialogues.text: Someone to speak with you. Grey is perplexed. Pamela rises, gathering herself.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA
dialogues.text: I'll go to the cafeteria.  23. She leaves and Nikolai enters, gruffly setting up the briefcase at the end of Grey’s bed. He snaps it open to reveal a crystal hi-def display screen. He moves over to and props his head up to view it, rearranging his pillows Eron’s face appears on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: It must be frustrating for a man like you to let someone else do that. Grey stares at the screen, surprised by Eron’s appearance ERON (CONT’D) You're somebody who liked to get things done with your own hands and now you can’t. Am I being too blunt?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: It’s okay. I like blunt. Every day for the past few months, I’ve been drowned in positivity. That’s the thing about becoming a quadriplegic - all the assholes of the world disappear. Everybody becomes the very best version of themselves around you.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Your condition gives people clarity. They see your struggle and they realize they've spent their lives griping about meaningless bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t be an inspiration to anybody. When there’s no more assholes left in the world, you quickly become the last one.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: I hear from the doctor that a computer saved you.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No, it didn’t. All it did was keep me alive. Letting me die would have been saving me. And when I get home, I’m gonna turn the computer off and get it right.  24.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: (awkwardly grasping for light) I spoke to Detective Cortez, the lead detective in your wife’s case. She said they had some promising suspects.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: People of interest. That’s the words she used. They don’t have any suspects.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Grey, what if I told you I could offer you something that would allow you to walk again? Would that count as good news? Grey is silent. That’s permission to continue. ERON (CONT’D) That computer I showed you, the one you took a dislike to. It has the potential to change everything for people in your condition.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Your little computer is gonna teach me how to walk?

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Actually it would do the walking for you. It would be inserted into your brain stem. As a quadriplegic, the line connecting your brain to your limbs has been cut. This chip would bridge that gap and talk to your limbs for you. (beat) They say it’s not ready for human testing yet. That’s what certain people tell me. I know it is.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: You think after all this...after everything...I’m going to let you put one of your computers inside me? That computerized car we were driving in is the reason I’m here.  25.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. Because I’m talking with someone who just told me they can’t wait to get home and give up on everything. I need someone who’s willing to bet their life that this will work, just like I would. Someone who can keep a secret from everyone they know and in doing so, make the world a better place. This chip has potential not just for spinal injuries, but for injuries of all kinds. A long beat. Grey stares at Eron, taking it in. ERON (CONT’D) The operation would have to be performed at Vessel. No hospitals.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So who would cut me open? You?

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (ON SCREEN)
dialogues.text: No. The best surgical robot in the world. If it goes wrong, it could kill you. If it goes right, you won’t just walk again, Grey. You’1l run.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The Victorian mansion that houses Vessel looms over us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An arched and austere OR. Grey lies on his stomach, out cold, strapped onto a chrom operating slab. The table rotates on the end of a ball- jointed gimbal that allows him to face in any direction. Eron and a young woman, DR. DIANA GORDON (33), stand at t back of the room, glaring at a row of large DSP monitors. The fluorescent lights on the ceiling go out, leaving onl pair of surgical lights. With stunning clarity, a huge PHOTOREALISTIC HOLOGRAM OF UV LIGHT fills the room, surrounding Grey. The image is of the INSIDE OF HIS NECK. entire vertebral body can be seen in three dimensions. Two ROBOT ARMS extend from the wall, hovering over Grey.  26. Eron holds up a glass tube with gloved hands. Inside the is a small black computer chip, the size of a fingernail. is the same chip we saw in Eron’s safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He frisks across the room, placing the tube in the finger one of the ROBOT ARMS. The hologram image of Grey’s neck appears on the front of the doctors. Dr. Gordon uses a scalpel, line across the top of Grey’s neck on the screen. The robot arms begin to perform the procedure as the surgeon with a laser. IN TIME LAPSE - we see the painstaking operation. tendons are cut away to reveal Grey’s brain stem screen in drawing a indicated by Muscle and -- one of the arms inserts the computer chip into his nec the clock ticks -- Grey is rotated on the slab -- the rob arms begin to sew him back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groggy. Grey’s eye’s peel open, blinking in the white lig He is lying on a gurney. His head is shaved. Eron and two other technicians are staring at him, along with

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON
dialogues.text: It’s going to feel strange initially. The neural pathways in your brain are now trying to have a conversation with a foreign body, and if it’s successful, that conversation will move your limbs. We need to take it in stages and not expect grand leaps while your brain learns to pass the baton, essentially. Grey nods. The doctor pushes on his legs.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you feel anything?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON
dialogues.text: Could you try moving your little finger on your right hand? Dr. Gordon. Grey glares down at it. Willing it to move. Nothing.  27.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My guess is that this is going to be a piecemeal process. She turns to face Eron.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be expecting unreasonable results so soon.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Please don’t talk. Let him concentrate. CLOSE ON Grey. His eyes drill his hand. Then, from nowhere, a VOICE. The voice is calm and very w spoken. A clearer, more human voice than any of the compu voices Grey has encountered before.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fingers moving. Then it happens. Grey's finger moves. It curls inward. Th other fingers follow and make a complete fist.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON
dialogues.text: With this technology, the key is to let it grow into itself. Never before has a bio-mechanical fusion been asked to do so much. As she says this, Grey raises his right arm above his hea The doctor wheels around and sees him. Her mouth drops op

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Now your other arm. Grey glares at his other arm, concentrating.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Arm moving. His left arm raises very slowly and shakily.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON
dialogues.text: This is...definitely unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Yes doctor, the ‘Department Of Lame Ways To Summarize World Changing Events’ is down the hall to the left. Thank you for your time.  28. Grey lowers his arm, totally amazed. Eron approaches, int

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Arm down.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Can you hear that voice? Every time I move my arm, I hear a voice telling it what to do.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: That’s Stem. I told you, you may hear his voice sometimes when he talks to your nervous system.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Stem?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: That’s what I call him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. GORDON
dialogues.text: His limbs have atrophied, no one should expect him to be running marathons just yet.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I don’t expect anything in this world, doctor, other than the deflating negativity of the medical profession. EXT. GREY’S HOUSE - DAY Grey’s mother Pam pulls up in her automated vehicle. She clambers out of the car, ambling toward the front door, lugging a bag of groceries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pamela shuffles inside, plopping the grocery bag on the g dining table. Grey is slumped in his wheelchair in the li room. He turns the chair to face her.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA
dialogues.text: Hi honey. I got you some of that mango you like. She absentmindedly unpacks the groceries.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did your rehab treatment go?  29. As she says this, Grey grips the sides of his wheelchair STANDS UP. His legs wobble as he does, still unsteady on feet. He takes a tentative step towards her, using two walking sticks.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you -- She turns to him, clutching a bag of mangoes. She FREEZES when she sees him, her words failing her, her mouth wide open. The mangoes drop to the floor, rolling across the w Grey takes another step. A tear runs down Pam’s face. Finally Grey reaches her, letting the crutches fall and wrapping his arms around her. She hugs him back, crying i his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: PAMELA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did you...how did this...? Grey stands back from her, smiling. Joyous.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I just couldn’t sit in that chair anymore. Pamela laughs and they hug again,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey holds himself up on a pair of bars, his legs danglin above a MOVING TREADMILL. The belt moves at a good pace a Grey is tentative. A baby taking his first steps. He dips his leg down, lifting it again. Apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: You can do it. He lowers his toes again, getting the speed of the belt u his feet. Then he let’s go of the bars. He falls instantly, SLAMMING down onto the treadmill. Ero and a female tech rush over, helping him up. ERON (CONT’D) Take a deep breath, focus and keep your eyes on this. He tacks a photo of ASHA onto the front of the treadmill. Grey eyes him, resents the tactic. He clambers back onto  30.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Turn it on.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: (to his tech) Do it. The belt on the treadmill whirs. Grey lowers his feet to They touch...and then they take. Grey is running. His angry determination melts into a WID GRIN. For the first time in a long time, he is happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey is dangling twenty stories above the city scape, his arms tremoring as he strains to hold on to a ledge.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eron is gaping with wonder and fear at a LARGE SCREEN. On he can see Grey, dangling from the ledge of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey sucks in a breath. Veins line his arms, pushed to th limits. Finally he can no longer hold on - he slips! He drops only a few feet before hitting a solid floor -- -- at which point, the 3D holographic image of the city BLINKS AND DISAPPEARS, revealing that we are actually in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a spare white room. Grey looks up at the wall opposite. Eron is looking in at through a large VIEWING WINDOW. Grey is now his creation. Eron steps away from the window and strides into the room

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: A twenty story fall to a bloody death will motivate anybody.  31.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I was always afraid of heights. It’s amazing how your brain gets convinced it’s real.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Now you have two brains working for you. One more than anyone else in the whole world has. (beat; with pride) State of the art technology with a classic skin.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So who is moving my arms and legs? Is it me or the computer? Am I --

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: It’s both, Stem works in service of your brain. You give Stem a command and he makes it happen. He's programmed to respond only to your thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Eron, I want you to know how thankful I am. To you. Eron turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: That’s my cue to leave before you try to hug me or something. And don’t thank me, I’m exploiting your limbs for my own research purposes.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: You could've picked anyone though.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: No, I couldn't have. You were the only quadriplegic I knew. INT. LIVING ROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - DAY Grey enters his house on his own two feet for the first t in a long time. He is carrying a large cardboard box mark CASE 103331. He sets the box down and cleaves the drapes open, sunligh drenching the room and highlighting an active sea of dust  32. IN MONTAGE - we see shots of Grey examining the CRIME SCE PHOTOS of his wife’s murder taped to the walls, along wit NEWSPAPER ARTICLES and WITNESS STATEMENTS. Grey grows increasingly exasperated as he pores over the documents, struggling to focus. INT. BEDROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - LATER Grey stares at a small bottle of morphine. He stabs a syr into it, drawing out a full shot. The needle hovers over vein. He moves to push the tip in but the needle stops.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What the fuck? His hand won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Grey is shocked to hear the question. Sits back.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Are you talking to me?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes. There is no one else I can talk to. A long, shocked beat.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I asked what you were doing.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Taking medicine.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Aren’t you concerned about the long term effects of using morphine?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No. I’m in pain. I need it. (beat) I should ask you why my hand isn’t moving?  33.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was simply concerned that you were harming yourself, Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m not. The opposite. I’m helping myself.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What’s hurting me is hearing a voice in my head like I’m a schizo, that’s what’s hurting me.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I won’t speak anymore unless absolutely necessary. Grey stares down at his hand. It moves again, depressing plunger into his vein. He relaxes back as the drugs relea ...swiftly falling into a DEEP SLEEP. INT. Grey both Eron

dialogues.speaker: PROTOTYPE TESTING ROOM, VESSEL HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: stands in front of Eron, reaching for the ceiling with arms, distracted. Something is clearly on his mind. is hunched over a handheld computer tablet, displaying an infrared image of Grey’s body, and checking off answer

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: No pain, no slowness? Grey takes a long beat to answer.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: What about response times? When you ask your arm to move, have you ever had a delayed movement? Come on, I need answers.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Not yet. Not that I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: How about when you wake up?  34.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: How long is this trial period?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Another two, three months. This is a crucial stage for us.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Eron...I want to ask you something.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: This voice I’m hearing...it does more than just repeat simple commands. It’s talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: What do you mean ‘talking to you’?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: It knows my name. It tells me when it thinks I’m doing something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Stem can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: It’s a voice in my head, Eron. That no one else can hear. If you’re telling me Stem can’t do that, that means I’m insane. INT. LIVING ROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - NIGHT The room is a mess. Grey studies the various reports, pac The video of his wife’s murder plays on the wall once aga Timecode digits tick across the bottom of the screen. Grey suddenly hurls the papers in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: God damn it!! He collapses onto his knees. A long beat of silence. Then

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can’t you see it? Grey looks up, taken by surprise.  35.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Can’t you see what’s right in front of you? Grey pauses, afraid and curious at once.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the tape. Grey hoists himself up, shuffling over to the television.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Freeze it at 01:52:16:33. Grey slows the image down. He pauses the image at the specified timecode - the EXACT moment when the Wiry Man f the gun into Asha’s head.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The gun.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is no gun in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: He had a gun. She was shot.

dialogues.speaker: STEM
dialogues.text: She was shot - but not with a gun he was holding in his hand. A gun implanted inside his hand. Grey leans in close to the image. He sees that the muzzle flash licks out of the Wiry Man’s hand, but that it appears to be coming straight from his palm.  36. Grey trembles, shaken to the bone by the fact that a voic his own head is questioning everything he thought he knew

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They also took Asha’s work papers. You can see it in the left of frame. Grey leans in again, watching the jerky image of one of t assailants squat down and retrieve a blurred object from Asha’s car.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Why would they take her papers? How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’ve been reading the police reports with you. Grey is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is a marking on the wrist of the man who takes the papers. Grey squints at the figure on the left of the screen. The image is far too washed out to see anything but a slight black dot on his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I can't see it.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Get closer. Grey obeys. FROM HIS POV - the screen enlarges as we CLOS on it, the pixels bleeding outwards and becoming huge. Th dots within dots that comprise the image become images themselves - we are now INSIDE the screen itself. The marking on the assailants wrist takes shape - a TATTO

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Get a pen and paper. Draw it.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I can’t draw.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can.  37. OUT OF POV - an astonished Grey races to the coffee table plucking up a notepad and pen. He watches as his hand sta at the paper - the quick strokes of a skilled illustrator Within seconds, he has sketched out a perfect BARCODE.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I’ve seen these...it’s a military tattoo. A guy who used to drive cranes with me has one on his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I will read it. Hold it in front of your eye. Grey holds the barcode up in front of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Brantner. Serk. Marine Corps. 098- 422. O-Positive. Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Jesus...you just...you just found this guy. Grey races to the glass table at the center of the room.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: on. The computer blazes to life across the glass.

dialogues.speaker: MONOTONE COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All clear. Good evening, Grey. How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: It just got a lot better. I need a phone number and an address. Brantner, S. Los Angeles area. The screen turns white, searching through a long list of phone numbers - finally narrowing it down to one.

dialogues.speaker: MONOTONE COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Brantner, S. 414 Citrus, Boyle Heights. 919 821 8484.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Boyle Heights. I got you, you son of a bitch!  38.

dialogues.speaker: MONOTONE COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Would you like me to call it?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Call Detective Cortez.

dialogues.speaker: MONOTONE COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Would you like me to call the Jane Cortez listed in your contacts, Grey?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Yes. I would.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why are you calling her?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So I can tell her we found him. The sound of a phone trills from the table, on loudspeake

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So that she can let him get away?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Hang up the call. The sound of the phone ceases. Grey sits in silence. GREY (CONT’D) It’s her job to catch these guys.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Having a job does not make you good at it. We have done more in five minutes than she did in months of work.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I...just think that...we need to at least tell her that --

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why did you have me inserted?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So I could walk again.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why did you have me inserted? A long, long beat.  39.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: So I could find them.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You need to be positive it’s him before you take any further action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Upper middle class neighborhood. Manicured lawns. Aspirat of real wealth. Grey lurks behind a street sign. It reads CITRUS AVE. He spying across the road at a nice, white house - number 41 He chews his fingernails, nervous. A lone male exits the house, locking up. He jumps into a driving car parked in the drive. A model similar to Asha’ The man is stocky. Dark hair. Is it one of the attackers?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Remember the license plate.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've logged it already. The car rolls past.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stay in a straight line when you cross the street. There are two security cameras on this street. If you stay on this line, you remain in their blind spot. Grey hustles across the street. We FOLLOW HIM to the FRON DOOR of the house. Grey squats down and jerks on the door handle. Locked. He knocks on the door. He waits, glancing around for onlookers. He knocks again, hard and loud. No answer. He retrieves a lock picking wrench and a paper clip from jacket. He slides the wrench in, working the paper clip a jimmying the lock. No good.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Damn it. His efforts produce nothing.  40.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Will you allow me to do it, Grey?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: You want to pick the lock without me?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Only with your permission.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Okay. And then, with sudden and precise dexterity, Grey’s hands move up and pick the lock. Grey watches his hands as if t were someone else’s, detached from them. The lock CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey crouches inside. An ALARM pings instantly, counting

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Stay calm. The keypad. Open it. Grey rips open a KEY PAD on the wall beside the door. Wit nimble expert fingers, he disconnects two wires, re-tying them. The alarm ceases. Grey exhales. He replaces the face of the key-pad and tre stealthily into the --

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: This is not the home of a street rat. Clean. Sparse. Grey moves past the walls, free of photos and art. There wrapped American flag in a glass case and a military meda

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey stalks into the kitchen. Sorts through mail - all of addressed to SERK BRANTNER. He hauls out a power bill. He spots an ashtray next to two cartons of CUBANO CIGARET There are six different matchbooks for a bar named THE LA CALL piled in the ashtray. He pockets one of them. He keeps moving to a glass table.  41.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: On. A computer screen image materializes on the glass surface password prompt blinks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey opens the closet, sorting through racks of clothes. finds a framed photo of a man in a military outfit. SUDDENLY - a noise interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey shoves the photo back into the closet, sprints out o the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey panics, drawing deep breaths.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Behind the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey launches into a hiding spot behind the front door. It opens slowly. A figure enters. This is SERK (32). He furrows his brow when the alarm doesn’t peal. Inspects it

dialogues.speaker: SERK
dialogues.text: What the hell? Grey is behind the door, holding his breath. Serk turns a from it and closes the door. Grey is right behind him. Serk scans the living room. Suspicious. All is quiet. Grey's chest rises and falls. A bead of sweat dribbles do his forehead. He glances down - sees the BARCODE tattoo stamped on Serk’s wrist. On his NECK, Grey sees the GANG TATTOO he saw the night of Asha’s murder. RAGE darkens Grey’s face. He raises his hands to attack S

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (calm, neutral) Wait.  42. Grey’s heart pounds. We hear it. Serk surveys the house. He steps forward. As he does, he glances at the GLASS CAS containing the American flag. WE ZOOM IN to it - reflecte the glass is the silhouette of GREY. Serk calmly places his car key on a coffee table -- and t SPINS AND LUNGES at Grey with a warcry! His hands wrap around Grey’s throat. Grey claws at Serk’s fingers, choking.

dialogues.speaker: SERK
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?! Shock bleeds into his eyes as he realizes who this is. SERK (CONT’D) Holy shit...you. Serk SLAMS Grey against the wall, burning with fury.

dialogues.speaker: SERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be walking. Let me get you a chair. He digs his fingers into Grey’s thorax, driving him to hi knees with ease. Grey is losing consciousness, fighting b with hits too weak to stop Serk.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: May I take over, Grey?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Fine! And with that, Grey spears his arms up between Serk’s and smashes them outwards. Serk falls forward and is greeted VICIOUS HEADBUTT from Grey. Serk staggers backwards, shaken. Dazed. Blood in his nose He launches himself at Grey, barraging him with a flurry quick blows. Each blow is EXPERTLY BLOCKED by Grey and th two of them grapple across the room into the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- large kitchen area. Serk keeps upping his game, kneein Grey in the ribs, then topping that with an elbow.  43. Grey grunts as he is hit, but effectively counters with b of his own. Serk HAMMERS his right arm down - which is ca by Grey. Grey picks Serk up and hurls him, jujitsu style, across t kitchen island, taking pots and pans with him. Serk SLAMS into the far wall, then hits the ground. He va to his feet instantly. He holds up his right arm and a BL SHEARS OUT OF THE SKIN IN HIS WRIST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey readies - his expression of fear belies his sudden physical prowess. As if he didn’t know how he was doing i Serk shears the air with the arm-blade, swiping at Grey. another swipe, this one slashing Grey’s arm. Grey contrac his stomach and ducks as Serk whips the blade back and fo Grey clamps Serk’s wrist, stopping the blade inches from face.

dialogues.speaker: SERK
dialogues.text: Okay, no more chairs. Let me get you a box. Serk DRIVES the knife down, the blade penetrating Grey's shoulder. Grey CRIES OUT - then he SPINS Serk around, usi his own arm to cut Serk’s throat. The blade sinks into the soft flesh, an arc of blood ribboning out onto the floor. Grey twists the blade and Serk SHUDDERS, clutching his th in befuddlement. Gargling “What the fuck?” through his ow blood. The blade RETRACTS into his arm and Serk drops silently. professional would be proud of this kill. Grey looms over him, shaking.

dialogues.speaker: SERK IS AKIMBO ON THE FLOOR, A CRIMSON POND HALOING HIS H
dialogues.text: Grey turns and vomits violently into the sink. Breathes h trying to keep from fainting.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I’ve gotta call Cortez. I’1l explain it...I can prove this guy is one of them. She’ll understand.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. Here’s what you’re going to do. You are going to remove any traces of your presence here. And quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey glares down at his shirt. It is covered in Serk’s bl

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. He finally pushes himself up from the sink, squinting dow Serk’s corpse.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One minute has now passed. Start by cleaning the --

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean one fucking minute, I meant...just give me a second.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: One second has now passed.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Just shut up! I need to think. Not let you do the thinking for me. He scans around, pacing. Panicked. Shaking. GREY (CONT’D) Jesus...I just cut somebody's throat. Grey’s arm reaches into his back pocket, pinching somethi out. It’s a piece of paper. Grey’s hands unfold it. It is photo of Asha from beside Grey’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s not just ‘somebody’s’ throat.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: When did you put this in my pocket?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This morning. Grey glares at his smiling wife. His breathing slows, his shaking subsides. He has calmed. A quiet determination no

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Alright, what do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I would suggest that we rid the house of all of your fingerprints.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I can’t remember everything I --  45.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have a record of every single thing you touched. This stops Grey short. Calms him somehow.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: First take your shoes off and wrap them in plastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN MONTAGE - we see RAPID SHOTS of Grey cleaning with a r wiping the walls down, wearing dish-washing gloves -- he wipes the face of the key-pad -- He moves to the KITCHEN - running the sink -- wiping down counter top - snatches up the mail he handled, drops it i a bag with his shoes -- we see TWO GARBAGE BAGS wrapped around his feet. THEY ARE INTERRUPTED BY A NOISE. A doorb

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I’m not killing anyone else today. Grey starts for the back door, then backs up and snatches a pack of cigarettes from Serk’s counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey leaps over the back fence, a cap pulled over his eye As he paces up the alley, carrying the plastic bag contai all the evidence, he hears a shrill SCREAM coming from wi the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crime scene tape ropes off the area. The street hums with police. Floodlights wash the area with harsh light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explosions of flash photography light the room. Forensics officers mill about above Serk’s corpse, sweat dotting th furrowed brows. They are all wearing special UV goggles.  46. Detective Cortez strolls in. A young detective, SCOTT BRE (25), scrambles in after her, following her like a lap do Has a slight crush on her. A huge one, actually. Awkward

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Girlfriend comes over, knocks on the door, no answer. She calls his phone, he doesn’t pick up so she comes in and finds his body. He offers her a pair of the techie goggles. She waves the off and takes out a notebook and pencil instead. He throw his own pair of goggles aside, mimicking her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I cannot believe you still use a notebook. You look like a cop in one of those corny old movies.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: I actually think those old movies are much better than the ones they make today. (beat) So what does this crime scene tell you?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: It tells me...you’ve got great eyes. Cortez snaps her fingers in his face.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Let’s go Don Juan, the first forty eight is ticking away rapidly here.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: No forced entry, no fingerprints in the whole place that aren’t his or the girlfriends, so --

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Right. So it’s not an impulsive crime of passion. He was killed by someone who knows him and knew what they were doing when it came to cutting someone’s throat. Cortez strolls around the kitchen, taking notes as she go She moves to the sink. The cabinets below it are open.  47.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: It looks like someone pulled out a few things.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Gloves to clean up the scene? She moves to another kitchen cabinet - opening it to reve THREE CARTONS of Cubano cigarettes. She stands up, bendin over and sniffing the sink grate.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: You smell something?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Smells like somebody puked.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: You've got a great nose too. Cortez turns to face Serk’s body, locking eyes with it.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: So why does a man we interviewed in relation to the murder of Asha Trace suddenly end up dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grey is running on a treadmill. Eron watches him from beh the pane of the observation room. Grey seems detached, irritated. Eron’s voice chimes in through a microphone system.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: Okay, that’s enough for today. Grey quickly stops running, dismounting the treadmill.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I need some more morphine. Grey tries the door of the simulation room. It doesn’t op

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Open up. Eron stares at Grey through the glass. Doesn’t move. GREY (CONT’D) Open the door, Eron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can track you, Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I can track you.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What does that mean in English?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: It means you have a piece of my property inside you. A very expensive piece of my property, built by me over many years. A microchip that could ease suffering around the world. Did you think I was going to let the piece of flesh that surrounds that microchip out of my sight for one second? Grey tenses. ERON (CONT’D) This morning I saw a news report about a murder at a home in Boyle Heights. Happened yesterday, around lunchtime. (beat) I know you’re the one who did it. I watched you go to that house on a tracking screen. I know every move you make. Eron holds up a tablet computer screen. On it, a small do pulses on a GPS map of the city.

dialogues.speaker: ERON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you realize that this operation has been done in secret? That if even the slightest thing goes wrong during this trial period, it’s all over? Did it occur to you that if you were to, say, commit murder, the authorities could find out about Stem and remove him from your body, putting you back in a wheelchair for life? The two men stare at each other, locked in a stand-off.  49.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: He was one of the guys who killed Asha, Eron.

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: So why didn’t you call the police?! I’ve worked my whole life for this and you're sticking your fucking fist in it! He thumps the glass, enraged.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: ERON
dialogues.text: I’ve been thinking about the answer to that question all morning. Prepared myself a speech. (beat) I am going to open that door and you are going to go home and carry on with your life as if everything was dandy. From now on, you will be a model patient. You won’t so much as jaywalk or litter a sidewalk until the end of this trial period. And no one but you and I will ever know where you were that day.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A grand, imposing brick building, built in the early nine hundreds, updated by modern additions of glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ceiling lamps throw intermittent pools of light into this sterile cavern of death. An Indian coroner, DR. BHATIA (43), leads Detective Corte Serk’s body. His corpse is displayed on a morgue slab, his skin peeled open in various sections, a surgical floodlight highlight every detail. Dr. Bhatia arches over the cadaver, prodding it with a scalpel.  50.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BHATIA
dialogues.text: When I examined the wound in his throat, I found wiring embedded in the tendons. So I’m thinking surgery. A medical implant, attached to the muscle. I follow the wire’s path...all the way to the arm. He turns the arm over. It has been flayed open with tweez Cortez sees it - metal. Living within the bed of bone and muscle is the RETRACTABLE BLADE we saw earlier.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DR. BHATIA
dialogues.text: Some sort of weapon implant, embedded within the muscle. Cortez leans in close.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BHATIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s more. I found computer implants all throughout his entire body. I’ve never seen anything to this extent before. In his arms, legs, stomach.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: What about the vomit sample we scraped from the sink? Bhatia moves over to a table, plucking up a sample jar.

dialogues.speaker: DR. BHATIA
dialogues.text: Food remnants - egg, mushroom - fingernail fragments - we pulled particles of engine grease from them. And the drug morphine in the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cortez hunches over a desk, facing two large panes of gla

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: ST cameras, 414 Citrus Avenue, Boyle Heights. Sixteenth of October, three PM.  51. IMAGES shimmer to life on the panes of glass. Security ca images similar to the footage of Asha’s murder. This time they display locked off shots of Serk’s house. Cortez uses her hand to wipe through the images, a TIMECO counter at the bottom of the screen flickering forward. Grey is nowhere to be seen in the video. Cortez is perple

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alley behind Citrus Ave, same day, three PM. The screens morph into a shot of the ALLEY WAY behind Ser house. Cortez whips through the footage. Then, at 4.14 PM she sees it. A dark figure, cap pulled low, exiting the alley at the bottom corner of the screen. Cortez studies the blurred figure. Is it Grey? INT. LIVING ROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - NIGHT Grey paces madly, smoking a cigarette. Sweating.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Smoking-related diseases kill one in ten adults globally.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, prison can kill you too.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Seven hundred and forty three adults per one hundred thousand will be sent to prison in the US. A much lower rate than the rate for smoking related deaths.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. Grey moves to a desk, opening a drawer. His needle and a or morphine awaits. He plucks both out.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is not a wise decision, Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Well, I’m the one making the decisions so too bad.  52. A knock at the door interrupts. Grey whirls, apprehensive He stashes the morphine, then darts to the door, grabbing crutches on the way. GREY (CONT’D) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s Jane. He opens the door a fraction. Cortez smiles, genuinely overwhelmed to see Grey standing.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. It takes a moment like this to realize that the simple act of opening a door is a miracle. Alabad a Dios. It’s good to see you, Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: You too, Detective.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: I heard you were walking again. I wanted to see it for myself.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Here I am. Pure willpower. I’m still on crutches, but...it’s a start.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: It’s amazing is what it is.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Come in. He guides her inside.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: I guess you’re biting your fingernails again?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: You told me it was a bad habit you used to have.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.  53.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: It’s the little things we take for granted. You can work on your car again. You can hug people.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, the person I want to hold most isn’t here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Yes. I know. I wanted to talk about that. I think...we may have some new information. Enough to reopen the case. I wasn’t going to let it go.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Do you want a coffee?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: No, I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: It’s no problem. This damn machine in the kitchen makes great coffee, I'll give it that. He hops out. Cortez looks around. She spots the smolderin cigarette in an ashtray. Next to the ashtray is a pack of Serk’s Cubano cigarettes. Cortez FREEZES on them.

dialogues.speaker: GREY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Milk? Sugar?

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Straight black, thanks. INT. KITCHEN, GREY’S HOUSE - SAME TIME Grey limps over to the kitchen counter. He looks back, spotting Cortez through the doorway. He sees that she has spotted the cigarettes. His face dro INT. LIVING ROOM, GREY’S HOUSE - SAME TIME Cortez turns around. GREY IS STANDING RIGHT BEHIND HER.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Grey...don’t --  54. Before she can say anything more, he is upon her. With ex skill and without his crutches, he disarms her and flips onto her back, WHIPPING her cuffs off her belt and clampi them around her wrists in one quick SNAP. The movement is so fluid that she is on the floor within seconds.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grey, don’t do this, I’m here to help you, I’m --

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Shut up. I don’t know what you think you know but I can’t let you stop me.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: This vigilante shit isn’t going to achieve a god damned thing.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s all I have to live for. He swipes the syringe and morphine from the drawer, then exits in a hurry. Cortez rolls over, barking into a small computer unit clipped to her belt.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Downtown 41, this is Cortez. Officer in need of assistance! INT. GREY’S GARAGE - NIGHT A side door explodes open. Grey sprints to his Mustang.

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No. The license plate is traceable. Logged by traffic cameras. You’1l have to run. And so Grey does, opening the garage door and disappearin into the night. Cortez stumbles out of the house, her cuf still around her wrists. She moves to the Mustang, squatting down and reading the plates. She jabbers into the computer on her belt.

dialogues.speaker: CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Last point of destination, vehicle number 4431-TMF.  55.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Point of destination logged, Vessel Computers, 817 Wilshire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ghost-like trails of steam rise up from sewer grates, pas piles of trash and graffiti streaked buildings. A homeless transient glances up from his makeshift camp, babbling to himself.

dialogues.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
dialogues.text: ...I mean, you can’t talk to me like that, I work hard....no I do not respect you....shut up then! Grey claws through his pocket, extracting the syringe.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Where’s the god damned morphine? (beat) Where is it?!

dialogues.text: Clearly you left it behind in your hurry, Grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t! What did you do with it?

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I can’t answer that, Grey. Grey keeps moving, reaching the end of the street. A neon sign looms above him - THE LAST CALL. A second man approaches and there is a smooth, surreptitious exchange between the

dialogues.speaker: STEM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We are here. Let’s go inside.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: No. Not yet.  56. Grey hustles across the street, fishing for cash. The sha male figure sits up, suspicious. He is AFRICAN AMERICAN,

dialogues.speaker: DRUG DEALER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Do you have...

dialogues.speaker: DRUG DEALER
dialogues.text: Look motherfucker, I may be ina wheelchair but I’ve got a cold piece of machinery on me that makes me a straight killer. He reaches into a sleeve on the wheelchair, pulling out a gleaming Beretta handgun.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: I just want to buy something...like morphine. I have cash. He shows the dealer a handful of cash. The dealer smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DRUG DEALER
dialogues.text: I don’t got no morphine. I got something a lot sweeter. He holds out a vial and they make the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: DRUG DEALER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hope you packed your bags and sunblock, boy. You goin’ on a trip.
